publicationStmt.p: This is an XML-TEI markup of the original publications by SIL Mexico for the purposes of: archival and for the creation of a body of Mixtepec-Mixtec language resources (LR) (ISO: mix). Encoded documents used with the permission of original authors and SIL Mexico.

notesStmt.note: Cuenta la leyenda que en el pueblo de Mixtepec había un sabino que creció muy alto. El árbol era tan alto que cuando llovía, se juntaban las nubes en su punta. De ahí se origina el nombre de Mixtepec que en mixteco es “Xini Viko” o “Xnuviko”, y significa ‘allá en las nubes’ o ‘donde bajan las nubes’.

sourceDesc.bibl:
Tuyuku ka'nu López Santiago, Samuel; Beckmann, Gisela Gómez Hernández, María. 2008. (2nd ed.). Instituto Lingüístico de Verano, A.C. Tlalpan, D.F., México
narrator Samuel López Santiago
Obtained from:

textDesc.channel: @mode:'w' means that the primary means of utilising this document is by reading it's written form;
textDesc.derivation: this document is labeled "original" because the XML-TEI markup of it's contents have not made any alterations to the original content;

normalization.ab: 2019-02-19Spelling of lexical items which in the old orthography were homographs and which have been changed according to updated working orthographic principles in:GUIA_ORTOGRAFICA_PRELIMINAR_Short_version.xml. Normalized forms are replaced in the value of w directly and the original (non-normalized) from is kept and recorded in the value of orig. Original forms which were normalized are Instances of "ña" still remain to be changed pending consultation with Mille (or other person working on orthography). Additionally, all saltillos ꞌ in the original content were changed to apostrophes ' with the reasoning that most people, writing in Mixtec, as well as using and searching thses resources will more easily have access to and use an apostrophe than a saltillo. This could be changed again in the future if waranted.

list.item: Mixtec content found at following locations: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg/w

English translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

Spanish translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

spanGrp.span: I will tell you a story that the elders used to tell.
Voy a contar un cuento que los ancianos contaban.
They said that this story was passed down nearby here around three or four hundred years in our past.
Dijeron que este cuento fue passado acerca de aquí desde cerca de tres o cuatro cientos años en nuestro passado.
They told of a big Sabine tree which stood and that had two trunks nearby the town's plaza that was there, nearby where the laguna was, they came and made the animal market by the riverbed.

Contaron de un Sabino alto que estaba parado y que tenía dos troncos cerca de la plaza del pueblo que estaba allí, cerca dónde estaba la laguna, dónde hicieron la plaza de los animales por la orilla del río.
put in as related entry to "nuya'vi"
this is a blend of "nuu" and "ya'vi". This is due to the occurance of the two with such high freqency 'in the/to the plaza'
There stood a big sabine tree that was so tall, (?) nearly around 60 meters or one hundred meters.
Allí estaba un gran sabino que era tan alto (?)... cerca de sesenta metros o cien metros.
Because of that it the sillouete of the tree was visible .....
"tuu vatsi karru ka" 'I see the car coming'
And then it started to rain nearby and there was a cloud over the tree.
Y empezó a llover cerca, y había un nube sobre el árbol.
why is the future potential copula used here?!
Because of that this town is called "down from the clouds".
Por esto este pueblo se llama "bajan las nubes".
This is how the people told it.
Es así que la gente contaron.
They said that this tree stood (?)..because it arose out of the water, because the lagoon was so big.
Decían que este arból estaba parado (?) porque se levantó del agua, porque la laguna era tan grande.
And then there was a (?) bowl and it was circling around in the water.
Then one day they wanted to pick it up.
Allí, se cayó en el agua.
Because of that (?), the people and relatives of the town said they chopped down the tree.
Por esto (?), la gente y parientes del pueblo dijeron que cortaron el árbol.
compare this form to the ones in L148, they are all different
And they do communal service day by day.
Y hicieron servicio comunál día a día.
When they arrived early in the morning, it grew back.
Cuando llegaron temprano en la mañana, volvió a estar como estaba.
is this 'arrive' or 'began'? and why is there not a "ni-"
the image shows them chopping the trunk not the branch
Then they chopped it down all day because God didn't allow it.
Y lo cortaron todo el día porque Díos no lo permitió.
And so the people of Mixtepec chopped down the tree.
And so they did it then it fell over.
Yentonces lo hicieron y se cayó.
verb with PRON-TREE or possesive + tree is the possessor
Because of that this tree is so big its branches went all the way to Tixitu.
Por esto este árbol es tan grande, sus ramas extendieron hasta Tixitu.
predicating adjective. How is tense marked (if at all) in such items?
And another branch extended all the way to (?placeName).
Y otra rama se extendió hasta (?placeName).
It was there that the trunk extended because this tree was so big.
Era allí hasta que su tronco se extendió porque este árbol era tan grande.
This is why they call our town "Top of the Clouds" or "Down from the Clouds".
Es debido a este árbol que nuestro pueblo se llama "Encima de las Nubes" o "Bajan las Nubes".
no "ña" here! This is relevant to BPT paper...instance of likely "ña" being dropped for just BPT.
So is "Xiní Vikó" another known/used name for Mixtepec!? This is also relevant for the BPT paper.
I am telling this story so that the people who go North teach it to their children because they don't know the legend of our town.
Estoy contando esta leyenda para que la genten que va al Norte la enseñen a sus niños porque no saben la leyenda de nuestro pueblo.
variant of "Chi kuchi", place in dictionary as related entry (etym: loanword)
slightly different usage, spectral variant from "speaking to (someone)"
Now, they don't teach our legend anymore.
Ahora, ya no enseñan nuestra leyenda.
